importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: NASA’s Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope detected the mysterious gamma-ray glow at the center of the Milky Way shortly after its launch in 2008, marking the beginning of a decades-long scientific inquiry into its origin.

The Cherenkov Telescope Array Observatory (CTAO), currently under construction, is expected to begin returning data in 2027, providing higher-resolution gamma-ray observations that could definitively confirm or reject the dark matter explanation for the galactic glow.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2008 to 2025 encompasses the detection of the gamma-ray glow by the Fermi telescope and the ongoing scientific debate between pulsar and dark matter origins, culminating in new simulations in 2025 that offer renewed support for the dark matter hypothesis.

keyTakeAways: A mysterious glow detected by NASA’s Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope at the center of the Milky Way has sparked debate between two explanations: pulsars (remnants of exploded stars) and dark matter collisions.

Dark matter, which makes up about five times more of the universe than regular matter, has long been theorized to exist, first by Swiss astronomer Fritz Zwicky in the 1930s and confirmed by Vera Rubin and W. Kent Ford in the 1970s through observations of galaxy rotation speeds.

Recent supercomputer simulations led by Joseph Silk of Johns Hopkins University show that dark matter could be distributed in an egg-shaped (non-spherical) structure at the galactic center, closely matching the observed shape of the gamma-ray glow.

This non-spherical shape challenges previous models that assumed dark matter was uniformly spherical, and now provides a stronger case for dark matter — particularly WIMPs (Weakly Interacting Massive Particles) — as the source of the glow.

The upcoming Cherenkov Telescope Array Observatory (CTAO), set to begin operations in 2027, will provide high-resolution gamma-ray data capable of definitively distinguishing between dark matter and pulsar origins.

While the new simulations don’t provide direct proof, they significantly bolster the possibility that dark matter, especially WIMPs, could be responsible for the glow and keep the WIMP hypothesis alive as a viable solution to the century-old dark matter mystery.

namedEntities.name: Joseph Silk
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professor of physics and astronomy at Johns Hopkins University and coauthor of a 2025 study on dark matter distribution.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Silk led the new supercomputer simulations showing that dark matter could have an egg-shaped distribution matching the observed gamma-ray glow.

namedEntities.name: Dark matter
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An invisible, non-luminous form of matter believed to constitute about five times more of the universe than visible matter.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The article presents dark matter as a leading candidate explanation for the mysterious gamma-ray glow at the center of the galaxy, with new simulations suggesting a plausible connection.

namedEntities.name: WIMPs (Weakly Interacting Massive Particles)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A leading theoretical candidate for dark matter that annihilates when two particles collide, producing gamma rays.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: WIMPs are proposed as a possible source of the gamma-ray glow, and the new simulations suggest that their collision could produce the observed glow in a non-spherical shape.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A mysterious gamma-ray glow at the center of the Milky Way, first detected by NASA’s Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope in 2008, has long been attributed to either pulsars or dark matter. While earlier models assumed dark matter was spherical, new simulations by Joseph Silk and colleagues show that dark matter could be distributed in a squashed, egg-shaped form at the galactic center — closely matching the observed glow's shape. This strengthens the dark matter theory, especially the WIMP hypothesis, which posits that colliding dark matter particles produce gamma rays. Despite no direct detection, the study suggests a 50% chance the glow is due to dark matter rather than old stars. With the upcoming Cherenkov Telescope Array Observatory (CTAO) set to begin operations in 2027, scientists will have high-resolution data to definitively confirm or rule out the dark matter explanation, making this a pivotal moment in the century-long search to identify dark matter.
title: Scientists Reconsider Dark Matter as Source of Mysterious Glow in Milky Way Center
